questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency department to evaluate an ongoing autoimmune disease. The patient’s mother reports, “We just came to this hospital from out of state; we left because those uneducated doctors could not figure out what is going on with my daughter. She has been ill since birth with several autoimmune diseases but has been more ill over the past several weeks.” The patient reports ongoing fatigue over the past several weeks. The mother has a past medical history of lupus, common variable immune deficiency, and diabetes. When the nurse comes into the room for IV placement, the mother requests a central venous catheter be placed because “Most nurses have difficulty placing an intravenous line in my daughter.” Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a very thin female in no acute distress with multiple track marks noted on the upper extremities bilaterally. A hospital band from another hospital is noted on the patient's right wrist. She demonstrates a sad and withdrawn affect. She has no hallucinations or delusions. The patient does not have suicidal or homicidal ideation. The patient's lab work, including a complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, electrocardiogram, and urinalysis, is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of vague symptoms and a questionable history of autoimmune disease. In addition, the physical examination is suspicious for recent hospitalizations and intravenous catheter placement. The willingness of this mother to have her daughter undergo a non-indicated and invasive medical procedure is highly questionable for factitious disorder imposed on another, also known as Munchausen syndrome by proxy. When this diagnosis is suspected, the first step involves immediate contact with child protective services for safety concerns.

Factitious disorder imposed on another refers to a psychiatric condition defined as a caregiver or parent intentionally faking or inducing symptoms in the patient for internal gain (e.g., sympathy, attention). This condition is more commonly found in females, healthcare workers, and patients with a history of physical or emotional trauma. Common presenting features include a patient that consistently presents with their caregiver with associated recurrent hospitalizations for a similar complaint, persistent symptoms after gaining attention, as well as an overeagerness for the patient to undergo invasive medical procedures. Often, the caregiver may cause real medical harm, such as via poisoning, administration of non-indicated medications, or intentional trauma.

In contrast to malingering, factitious disorder reflects self-induced or fake symptoms for internal gain and is produced unconsciously. Malingering, on the other hand, results from feigning or exaggeration of physical or psychological symptoms to achieve external gain, reflecting a conscious motivation for secondary gain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Factitious disorder imposed on another  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vulnerable child syndrome  :
Incorrect: Vulnerable child syndrome refers to a caregiver or parent's extreme manifestation of persistent and unfounded expectations of medical vulnerability following a serious disease or life-threatening event for the child.  
❌ Somatic symptom disorder  :
Incorrect: Somatic symptom disorder refers to a psychiatric condition that involves at least one unexplained physical symptom for greater than six months without a clear underlying pathophysiologic diagnosis.  
❌ Conversion disorder  :
Incorrect: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder, results when one or more neurological symptoms arise due to an underlying stressful event or an experience of emotional or physical trauma.  
❌ Malingering  :
Incorrect: Malingering refers to a feigning or exaggeration of physical or psychological symptoms with the intent to achieve the desired outcome, reflecting a conscious motivation for secondary gain.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate a wound infection. The patient reports an abscess that needs to be drained on her right lower extremity. The patient states, “I don’t know why, but I keep getting these skin infections. I don’t use intravenous drugs, so something must be wrong with my immune system.” The patient does not have any significant past medical history, does not use illicit drugs, and does not drink alcohol. The patient currently works as a nursing assistant at an outside hospital. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a  3 cm x 3 cm abscess over the anterior tibia. Scattered track marks are noted throughout her bilateral lower extremities. The patient has an admission band from a nearby hospital around her left wrist. Urine drug screen is negative. After the physician leaves the room, the patient is found injecting saline into a vein in the opposite leg. Which of the following best describes the symptom origin and motivation for this patient's underlying condition?

choices.text: Intentional feigning or inducing symptoms for sympathy or attention
Intentional feigning of symptoms for secondary gain
Unintentional feigning of symptoms without secondary gain
Intentional feigning or inducing symptoms on another for sympathy or attention
Unintentional feigning of minimal symptoms without secondary gain

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is concerning for factitious disorder imposed on self, given her history of working in the healthcare field and recurrent self-inflicted soft tissue abscesses. This disorder reflects an intentional feigning or inducing symptoms for sympathy or attention.

Several disorders including malingering, factitious disorder, and factitious disorder imposed on another reflect intentional feigning or inducing of symptoms for attention, sympathy, or secondary gain (such as is the case in malingering). In contrast, somatic symptoms and related disorders such as illness anxiety disorder, vulnerable child syndrome, and conversion disorder reflect unintentional symptom perception. In this cluster of disorders, symptoms are unconsciously produced due to an origin in underlying anxiety or recent physical/emotional trauma. These patients truly believe their symptoms are real, making them difficult to treat.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intentional feigning or inducing symptoms for sympathy or attention  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intentional feigning of symptoms for secondary gain  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the symptom origin and motivation for malingering, not factitious disorder imposed on self, which is the more likely the case in this patient.  
❌ Unintentional feigning of symptoms without secondary gain  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the symptom origin and motivation for patients with somatic symptom disorder or conversion disorder. In both of these disorders, patients unintentionally feign symptoms without motivation for secondary gain.  
❌ Intentional feigning or inducing symptoms on another for sympathy or attention  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the symptom origin and motivation for patients with underlying factitious disorder imposed on another (Munchausen syndrome by proxy). The patient in this situation likely has a factitious disorder imposed on self.  
❌ Unintentional feigning of minimal symptoms without secondary gain  :
Incorrect: Patients with illness anxiety disorder do not present with significant symptoms, and if present, the symptoms are often minimal or related to underlying anxiety.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to evaluate a cough. The mother states, “he’s been coughing all week, and I’m so worried he has pneumonia. We saw our pediatrician earlier today who said everything was fine, but he must be missing something!” The patient has a past medical history of NICU admission for respiratory distress in the newborn. He has since been without complications or recurrent hospitalizations. Chart review indicates that this is the patient's fourth emergency department visit for these symptoms over several months. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a toddler playing with trucks on the ground with clear rhinorrhea from the nares. Cardiopulmonary auscultation is within normal limits. A chest radiograph is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a benign upper respiratory tract infection with a history of multiple visits to the emergency department and primary care doctor, all with unremarkable work-ups. Given this patient’s NICU admission history and a parent who unrealistically believes in an ongoing serious pathologic process, the most likely diagnosis is vulnerable child syndrome (VCS). 

VCS refers to a caregiver or parent's extreme manifestation of persistent and unfounded expectations of medical vulnerability following a serious disease or life-threatening event. The majority of cases occur in patients who have a history of admission to the NICU; however, cases also occur in patients who have sustained significant trauma, are admitted to a pediatric intensive care unit, or who have undergone surgical procedures. VCS ultimately damages the patient and healthcare system, with repeated absences from school, social and emotional delay, and overuse of healthcare resources.

In contrast to factitious disorder imposed on another, VCS does not involve secondary gain for attention or emotional appeasement. In VCS, the caregivers bring their child for evaluation due to genuine concern for their health; however, their intention is often rooted in unresolved conflict from prior inciting events.  

Option Analysis

✅ Vulnerable child syndrome  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Munchausen syndrome by proxy  :
Incorrect: Munchausen syndrome by proxy refers to a caregiver or parent intentionally faking or inducing symptoms in the patient for internal gain (e.g., sympathy, attention). This disorder should be suspected in patients with a history of recurrent hospitalizations with negative or inconclusive workups and a caregiver’s over-eagerness to consent for the patient to undergo invasive procedures.  
❌ Somatic symptom disorder  :
Incorrect: Somatic symptom disorder is a psychiatric condition involving at least one unexplained physical symptom for greater than six months without a clear underlying pathophysiologic diagnosis.  
❌ Conversion disorder  :
Incorrect: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder, results when one or more neurological symptoms arise due to an underlying stressful event or an experience of emotional or physical trauma.  
❌ Malingering  :
Incorrect: Malingering refers to a feigning or exaggeration of physical or psychological symptoms with the intent to achieve the desired outcome, reflecting a conscious motivation for secondary gain.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. The patient reports the chest pain worsens with exertion and is relieved with rest. He states, “It feels like an elephant is sitting on my chest.” He reports similar pain in the past, which has been relieved with opiates; he is inquiring if he could have equal treatment at this time. The patient has a past medical history of myocardial infarction, diabetes, hypertension, and chronic lymphedema. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and drinks six beers daily. This is the patient’s third visit to the emergency department this month for evaluation of similar symptoms—prior workups have all been unremarkable. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, the patient sits comfortably in bed in no acute distress. A screening electrocardiogram is demonstrated below.  


Reproduced from: wikipedia   
Laboratory studies reveal cardiac enzymes within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department to evaluate recurrent chest pain with previously negative workups. Overall, this patient's presentation is consistent with malingering, likely secondary to seeking opioids.

Malingering refers to feigning or exaggeration of physical or psychological symptoms with the intent to achieve the desired outcome. Patients who present with malingering commonly are uncooperative, are not satisfied with negative results, and have complete resolution symptoms once their secondary gain has been achieved. The most common secondary gain outcomes include prescription of controlled substances, time off of work, financial gain, or shelter placement.

In contrast to factitious disorder, malingering reflects a conscious motivation for secondary gain, whereas factitious disorder reflects an unconscious motivation for secondary gain. Additionally, the secondary gain associated with the factitious disorder is more commonly internal rather than external.  

Option Analysis

✅ Malingering  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Factitious disorder  :
Incorrect: Factitious disorder (also known as Munchausen syndrome) is a psychiatric condition in which patients unconsciously fake or induce symptoms for secondary gain.  
❌ Somatic symptom disorder  :
Incorrect: Somatic symptom disorder is a psychiatric condition involving at least one unexplained physical symptom for more than six months, without a precise underlying pathophysiologic diagnosis.  
❌ Conversion disorder  :
Incorrect: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder, results when one or more neurological symptoms arise due to an underlying stressful event or an experience of emotional or physical trauma.  
❌ Acute myocardial infarction  :
Incorrect: This patient’s vital signs are within normal limits, and a routine electrocardiogram does not demonstrate evidence of ST-elevations with reciprocal depressions.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician to evaluate right leg weakness for two weeks. The patient states, “I can’t lift my right leg, and it feels numb too. I haven’t been able to walk or go to school because of my symptoms.” The patient's parent states, “I don’t know what’s wrong. I know school has been hard this year with her applying to college, but all of this just came out of the blue.” The patient is otherwise healthy and neither uses illicit substances nor consumes alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has 2+ symmetric reflexes in the bilateral lower extremities on physical examination. Plantar reflex testing results in flexion of the big toe bilaterally. While the patient lies supine, the physician places a hand under the right heel; when asked to lift the left leg against resistance, the patient exerts downward pressure with the right heel. Further history gathering is most likely to reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient presents for evaluation of spontaneous right lower extremity weakness. Physical examination demonstrates a positive Hoover sign, a technique used to differentiate between the actual and functional weakness of the lower extremities. When asked to raise the unaffected leg, patients with functional weakness will exert downward pressure on the affected heel. Together, these findings are suspicious for conversion disorder, often triggered by recent emotional or physical trauma.

Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder, refers to at least one neurological symptom related to voluntary movement or sensory function inconsistent with known neurologic or medical disease. This condition is often triggered by a recent stressful event or an  experience of physical or emotional trauma. This condition is more commonly found amongst teenagers and young adults. A notable finding with this condition is the “la belle indifference,” where patients describe their symptoms without urgency, fear, or anxiety.

An essential component in evaluating patients with this disorder is differentiating between true and functional neurological symptoms. Many examination maneuvers exist to aid this differentiation, including the Hoover sign.  

Option Analysis

✅ Recent emotional or physical trauma  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recent “bulls-eye” rash  :
Incorrect: Lyme disease, or infection with Borrelia burgdorferi, can result in peripheral nervous system disorder, most notably Bell palsy. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with conversion disorder.  
❌ Recent episode of diarrhea  :
Incorrect: Campylobacter jejuni is often the precipitating organism implicated in the development of Guillain-Barré syndrome. This condition presents decreased reflexes and bilateral ascending weakness starting with the lower extremities.  
❌ Family history of demyelinating disease  :
Incorrect: Multiple sclerosis is characterized by relapsing-remitting neurologic symptoms, including weakness as well as sensory or visual disturbances. This patient's weakness is most likely functional, given her positive Hoover sign.  
❌ Recent heavy lifting  :
Incorrect: Lumbar radiculopathy can present with unilateral leg weakness; however, this patient is without back pain or radicular symptoms, and she has a negative Babinski sign bilaterally.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate recurrent tingling in her right upper extremity. The patient reports, “I woke up with tingling in my right arm again today, and I think I might be having a stroke.” The patient has no past medical history and does not take any medications daily. The patient is currently enrolled in graduate school, smokes marijuana occasionally, and consumes alcohol socially. This is the 8th emergency department visit with similar complaints over the past year. The patient has had multiple negative workups, including CTs and MR imaging of the brain and evaluation by multiple neurologists. Vital signs are within normal limits. The neurologic evaluation demonstrates 5/5 strength in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. The patient states sensation to light touch is 50% on the right upper extremity when compared to 100% on the left upper extremity.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of recurrent right upper extremity tingling that has been thoroughly evaluated and present for more than six months. This history is most consistent with somatic symptom disorder, which is best treated by providing reassurance and supportive measures.

Somatic symptom disorder is defined by at least one unexplained physical symptom that has been present for ≥ 6 months. Common physical symptoms include vague neurologic complaints, back pain, gastrointestinal symptoms, or pelvic pain. Patients with somatic symptom disorder are frequently anxious about their health, self-diagnosed, and mistrust the physician's diagnosis, often demanding repeat evaluation via imaging, blood work, or specialty consultation.

Appropriate management of somatic symptom disorder aims to provide reassurance and supportive measures to the patient. It is essential to acknowledge the validity of the patient’s symptom(s) while reinforcing that medical disease has been ruled out. Additional therapy involves treating comorbid psychiatric or active medical conditions, limiting prescriptions and referrals, and maintaining regularly scheduled outpatient appointments that are not contingent upon symptoms.  

Option Analysis

❌ Vulnerable child syndrome  :
Incorrect: Vulnerable child syndrome refers to a caregiver or parent’s extreme manifestation of persistent and unfounded expectations of medical vulnerability following a serious disease or life-threatening event in the patient’s life.  
❌ Munchausen syndrome by proxy  :
Incorrect: Munchausen syndrome by proxy refers to a caregiver or parent intentionally faking or inducing symptoms in the patient in order for internal gain (e.g., sympathy, attention). This disorder should be suspected in patients with a history of recurrent hospitalizations with negative or inconclusive workups and an over-eagerness for the patient to undergo invasive procedures.  
✅ Somatic symptom disorder:
Correct:  See Main Explanation.  
❌ Conversion disorder  :
Incorrect: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder, results when one or more neurological symptoms arise due to an underlying stressful event or an experience of emotional or physical trauma.  
❌ Malingering  :
Incorrect: Malingering refers to a feigning or exaggeration of physical or psychological symptoms with the intent to achieve the desired outcome, reflecting a conscious motivation for secondary gain.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. The patient reports recurrent chest pain worsened with exertion over several weeks. The patient states, “I’m not sure what is going on. I’m worried I might be having a heart attack – please, you have to consult the cardiac catheterization lab!” The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and a family member who suffered a heart attack before 50. She does not take any medications daily. Chart review shows similar, recurrent presentations to several nearby hospitals over the past month. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient’s physical examination demonstrates bandaids over the antecubital fossa bilaterally. The cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. The patient is noted to have a 2 cm left groin hematoma with an overlying adhesive dressing. An electrocardiogram demonstrates a normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent chest pain and recurrent hospitalizations for a similar complaint. The physical examination is suspicious for recent cardiac catheterization, which likely reflects this patient's openness towards invasive procedures. Together, this presentation is most consistent with factitious disorder imposed on self, also known as Munchausen syndrome.

Factitious disorder imposed on self refers to a psychiatric condition defined as a patient intentionally faking or inducing symptoms for internal gain (e.g., sympathy, attention). This condition is more commonly found in females, healthcare workers, and patients with a history of physical or emotional trauma. Standard presenting features include recurrent hospitalizations for a similar complaint, persistent symptoms after gaining attention, as well as an overeagerness to undergo invasive medical procedures.

In contrast to malingering, factitious disorder reflects self-induced or fake symptoms for internal gain and is produced unconsciously. On the other hand, malingering results from feigning or exaggerating physical or psychological symptoms to achieve external gain, reflecting a conscious motivation for secondary gain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Factitious disorder  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Factitious disorder by proxy:
Incorrect: Factitious disorder refers to a psychiatric condition where patients intentionally fake or induce symptoms to gain attention. Factitious disorder by proxy occurs when another individual imposes illness on the patient (such as a parent declaring their healthy child is sick), rather than the patient feigning illness themselves.  
❌ Somatic symptom disorder  :
Incorrect: Somatic symptom disorder is a psychiatric condition involving at least one unexplained physical symptom for more than six months, without a precise underlying pathophysiologic diagnosis.  
❌ Conversion disorder  :
Incorrect: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder, results when one or more neurological symptoms arise due to an underlying stressful event or an experience of emotional or physical trauma.  
❌ Malingering  :
Incorrect: Malingering refers to a feigning or exaggeration of physical or psychological symptoms with the intent to achieve the desired outcome, reflecting a conscious motivation for secondary gain.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of difficulty sleeping. The patient states, “Doctor, I can’t sleep. There has to be something wrong. I think I need another CT scan of my brain.” The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. The patient's mother died from glioblastoma multiforme three years ago. When questioned further, the patient has been reading about brain tumors for multiple hours per day and has lost interest in activities he used to enjoy. The patient has started taking nutritional supplements and exercising excessively in an attempt to prevent cancer. This is the patient's 4th emergency department visit with similar presentations in the past six months. Vital signs are within normal limits, and neurologic examination is non-focal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with excessive worry regarding the development of malignancy and anxiety about health without experiencing actual somatic symptoms, which is most consistent with the diagnosis of illness anxiety disorder.

Illness anxiety disorder refers to excessive worry about having or developing a serious medical illness for ≥6 months. Patients with this disorder frequently present to their primary care physician, urgent care, or emergency departments demanding advanced imaging, blood work, and specialty consultation to ease their apprehensions. Some patients with severe illness anxiety often avoid situations that make them confront their illness (or lack thereof), such as the doctor’s office.

In contrast to patients with somatic symptom disorder, patients with illness anxiety disorder do not experience somatic symptoms. If they experience symptoms, they are more often a manifestation of underlying anxiety, including sleeplessness, difficulty concentrating, and obsessive thoughts.  

Option Analysis

✅ Illness anxiety disorder  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Somatic symptom disorder  :
Incorrect: Somatic symptom disorder is defined by at least one unexplained physical symptom that has been present for greater than or equal to 6 months. Treatment involves reassurance and reinforcement that medical disease has been ruled out.  
❌ Conversion disorder  :
Incorrect: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder, results when one or more neurological symptoms arise due to an underlying stressful event or an experience of emotional or physical trauma.  
❌ Factitious disorder  :
Incorrect: Factitious disorder refers to a psychiatric condition in which patients intentionally fake or induce symptoms in order to gain attention.  
❌ Major depressive disorder  :
Incorrect: This patient has some features of major depressive disorder, such as anhedonia and difficulty sleeping. However, he does not meet the DSM criteria for this diagnosis.
